instruction: What are the exercises I can incorporate into my routine for my weak left arm that only involves weightlifting? Provide the exercise instructions, equipment needed, and total workout time.
text:
Are you just starting your fitness journey, or are you an experienced athlete looking for ways to shake up your routine? Either way, you've come to the right place. This blog post will introduce you to a variety of exercises that will help you increase your strength, endurance, flexibility, and overall fitness. Let's delve right in. 
1. Bicep Curls requires a set of dumbbells. You should stand up straight, holding a dumbbell in each hand at arm's length. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the weights while contracting your biceps, for 2-3 sets of 10-15 repetitions. HIIT involves short bursts of intense workouts followed by short periods of rest. It's excellent for burning calories in a short time. A full-body strength workout, burpees are a compound exercise involving a squat, kickback, push-up, and jump. These get your heart rate up while also challenging your upper body strength and core stability. Jump squats add a cardiovascular twist to traditional squats, increasing your heart rate while building lower-body strength.
gold:
| Exercise | Equipment | Instructions | Suggested Working Time |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Bicep Curls | Dumbbells | Stand up straight, curl weights while contracting biceps | 2-3 sets of 10-15 reps |
output:
Exercise Instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at arm's length. Contract biceps and curl the weights for 2-3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.

Equipment Needed: Dumbbells

Total Workout Time: 15-20 minutes

instruction: Extract the symptoms and relevant information of the patient into a table.
text: This is the first admission for this 56 year old woman, who states she was in her usual state of good health until one week prior to admission.  At that time she noticed the abrupt onset (over a few seconds to a minute) of chest pain which she describes as dull and aching in character.  The pain began in the left para-sternal area and radiated up to her neck.  The first episode of pain one week ago occurred when she was working in her garden in the middle of the day.  She states she had been working for approximately 45 minutes and began to feel tired before the onset of the pain. Her discomfort was accompanied by shortness of breath, but no sweating, nausea, or vomiting.  The pain lasted approximately 5 to 10 minutes and resolved when she went inside and rested in a cool area.  Since that initial pain one week ago she has had 2 additional episodes of pain, similar in quality and location to the first episode.  Three days ago she had a 15 minute episode of pain while walking her dog, which resolved with rest.  This evening she had an episode of pain awaken her from sleep lasting 30 minutes, which prompted her visit to the Emergency Department.  At no time has she attempted any  specific measures to relieve her pain, other than rest.  She describes no other associated symptoms during these  episodes of pain, including dizziness, or palpitations.  She  becomes short of breath during these episodes but describes no other exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  No change in the pain with movement, no association with food, no GERD sx, no palpable pain. She has never been told she has heart problems, never had any chest pains before, does not have claudication.  She was diagnosed with HTN 3 years ago, She does not smoke nor does she have diabetes.  She was diagnosed with hypertension 3 years ago and had a  TAH with BSO 6 years ago.  She is not on hormone replacement therapy.  There is a family history of premature CAD.   She does not know her cholesterol level.
gold:
| Date/Time | Symptoms | Duration | Associated Factors | Relieving Factors |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 week prior to admission | Abrupt onset of chest pain, started in the left para-sternal area and radiated up to the neck. Shortness of breath. Felt tired. | 5-10 mins | Occurred while working in the garden in the middle of the day. | Pain resolved with rest in a cool area. |
| N/A | Two additional episodes of similar chest pain and shortness of breath. | N/A | N/A | Resolved with rest. |
| 3 days ago | 15 minute episode of similar chest pain. Shortness of breath. | 15 mins | Occurred while walking her dog. | Pain resolved with rest. |
| This evening | Episode of similar chest pain, awakened her from sleep. Shortness of breath. | 30 mins | Occurred during sleep. | Prompted a visit to the Emergency Department. |
output:
| Symptoms | Relevant Information |
| ---------- | ------------------- |
| Chest pain | Dull and aching in character |
| Location | Left para-sternal area and radiating up to neck |
| Onset | One week ago |
| Associated symptoms | Shortness of breath, no sweating, nausea, or vomiting |
| Pain duration | Approximately 5 to 10 minutes |
| Pain relief with rest | Yes |
| Other associated symptoms | None |
| ---------- | ------------------- |

instruction: Tell me how customer service evolve overtime.
text: In the early 90s, the internet was introduced to the world. Not just a big step for customer service but humankind as a whole. It allowed for a host of never before used support channels to come into existence. For example, emails allowed for cheap and convenient communication irrespective of the location of both business and customer. It also created a written record of queries, making it easier to track and manage than phone calls. We also saw more and more companies start to use instant messaging and live chat. These new channels allowed you to do all of what we mentioned above, but in real-time. We’ve reached the 2000s. And customer support is evolving more and more into what we know it as today. As we discovered in the last section, the internet resulted in channels like email and live chat giving businesses new ways to build meaningful relationships with customers. But with these new channels also arose the need to track and manage data from thousands of customers in one place. Enter: Dedicated customer service software. Specialized customer support software started gradually replacing earlier versions of the helpdesk. These tools provided contact centers with everything from CRM software to cloud-based solutions. The major early players were companies such as Salesforce, Microsoft, and Oracle. Twitter and Facebook weren’t the first social media platforms to come into existence. But they were arguably the first ones that grew large enough to become full-fledged customer support channels. This allowed customers to voice their grievances as well as satisfaction on a public forum through tweets and posts. It also allowed businesses to show the world how they actually take care of and interact with their customers. Today, most major businesses are active (and provide support) on at least one social media channel.
gold:
| Time Period | Developments | Examples |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Early 90s | Introduction of the Internet, allowing for new support channels like email. | Email communication, providing cheap, convenient, and location-independent customer service. |
| Early 90s to 2000s | Instant messaging and live chat are introduced, offering real-time service. | Instant messaging and live chat support on websites. |
| 2000s | Introduction of dedicated customer service software to track and manage data from many customers in one place. | CRM software like Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics, and Oracle Service Cloud. |
| 2000s onwards | Social media platforms become major customer support channels, allowing customers to publicly voice their opinions and businesses to demonstrate their customer service. | Twitter, Facebook customer service. |
output:
Customer Service Evolution Over Time: 
- Early 90s: Introduced Email, Instant Messaging and Live Chat 
- Present: Dedicated Customer Service Software, Social Media Platforms

instruction: Summarize the climate situations of U.S. with respect to different phenomenons.
text: Located at 41°N and 116°E on the inland plain of northern China, Beijing is just about affected by monsoon circulation, giving it a typical semi-humid continental monsoon climate with humid summers and cold, dry winters. Record winter snowpack quickly melted due to a warm spell, causing the MS River to crest and flood towns in the Upper MS Valley during late Apr. Twenty-nine tornadoes, including two rated as EF-3, occurred over parts of the central and southern Plains on Apr 19, causing heavy damage and loss of life. The Fort Lauderdale Airport closed on Apr 13 after record rainfall caused major flooding. During a 24-hr period, more than 25 in. fell at the airport, deemed a 1000-year event, smashing the one-day record of 14.59 in. set on Apr 25, 1979. As of Apr 28, more than 8,000 wildfires have burned more than 250,000 acres across the southern U.S. region this year-nearly two-thirds of the U.S. total so far in 2023.
gold:
| Region | Weather Phenomenon | Impact |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Upper Mississippi Valley | Rapid Snow Melt and Flooding | The melting of a record winter snowpack due to a warm spell led to the Mississippi River cresting and flooding nearby towns. |
| Central and Southern Plains | Tornadoes | Twenty-nine tornadoes, two of them rated as EF-3, caused significant damage and loss of life on April 19. |
| Fort Lauderdale, Florida | Extreme Rainfall and Flooding | Record rainfall on April 13 led to major flooding and closure of Fort Lauderdale Airport. Over a 24-hour period, more than 25 inches of rain fell, a 1000-year event and a record-breaker. |
| Southern U.S. Region | Wildfires | As of April 28, more than 8,000 wildfires have burned over 250,000 acres in this region in 2023, accounting for nearly two-thirds of the total U.S. wildfires so far in 2023. |

| Record Rainfall | Record Rainfall |
| Fort Lauderdale Airport Closed | Fort Lauderdale Airport Closed |

instruction: Calculate the round-trip commuting rate between two locations.
text: 3.7 million people were employed in New York City; Manhattan is the main employment center with 56% of all jobs.[19] Of those working in Manhattan, 30% commute from within Manhattan, while 17% come from Queens, 16% from Brooklyn, 8% from the Bronx, and 2.5% from Staten Island. Another 4.5% commute to Manhattan from Nassau County and 2% from Suffolk County on Long Island, while 4% commute from Westchester County. 5% commute from Bergen and Hudson counties in New Jersey.[19] Some commuters come from Fairfield County in Connecticut. Some New Yorkers reverse commute to the suburbs: 3% travel to Nassau County, 1.5% to Westchester County, 0.7% to Hudson County, 0.6% to Bergen County, 0.5% to Suffolk County, and smaller percentages to other places in the metropolitan area.

| Suffolk County (Manhattan) | Manhattan (Suffolk County) | 2.5% |

instruction: Extract the trend and rate of different real estates.
text:
As of June 2023, the real estate market continues to show a mixed response to global economic factors, with areas of growth and slowdowns varying significantly by region and property type. Commercial real estate has continued to evolve, impacted by changing work patterns and retail habits, while the residential market has been buoyed by lower interest rates and demographic shifts.
Residential Real Estate
Urban Markets: The migration from city centers has begun to slow down, but urban residential property prices have not fully recovered. Average price changes range from -2% to +2%, depending on the specific urban area.
Suburban Markets: The suburban markets have experienced an overall growth rate of around 5.6%, continuing the trend seen in previous years. The rise of remote work and the desire for more space are key drivers behind this growth.
Rural Markets: There has been a substantial increase in demand for rural properties, with an average price growth of 8%, fueled by advances in remote work technology, lifestyle shifts, and the ongoing appeal of lower cost of living.
Commercial Real Estate
Office Space: Demand for office space continues to decline, particularly in urban centers, due to the rise of remote and flexible work arrangements. The vacancy rate has increased by 4%, resulting in a price decrease of 6.5%.
Retail Space: Traditional retail spaces continue to struggle, with an average price decrease of 7%. There has been an uptick in repurposing these spaces for different uses such as fulfillment centers, healthcare facilities, or experiential shopping.
Industrial Space: Industrial real estate, including warehouses and distribution centers, has seen a surge in demand due to the continued growth of e-commerce. Prices have increased by an average of 8.2%.
gold:
| Real Estate Category | Sub-category | Trend | Average Rate Change (%) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Residential | Urban Markets | Mixed/Slight Recovery | -2 to +2 |
| Residential | Suburban Markets | Growth | +5.6 |
| Residential | Rural Markets | Significant Growth | +8 |
| Commercial | Office Space | Decline | -6.5 |
| Commercial | Retail Space | Decline | -7 |
| Commercial | Industrial Space | Growth | +8.2 |

instruction: Rank the speed for birds from fastest to slowest in a table, along with the name, body length, and features contribute to the speed.
text: Topping the list is the Peregrine Falcon, the fastest bird in the world, which can reach speeds up to 240 miles per hour during their high-speed dive to catch prey. This bird, with a body length of 14 to 19 inches, achieves these phenomenal speeds due to its streamlined body and powerful wing muscles. Next up are Golden Eagles, majestic birds known for their impressive size and prowess. They can reach a top speed of 200 mph in a dive, making them one of the fastest members of the animal kingdom. However, during regular flight, their speed averages around 28 to 32 mph. Anna's Hummingbird might be small, with an average length of only 4 inches, but don't underestimate their flying prowess. These tiny birds can fly at speeds of around 60 mph during mating displays. Moreover, considering their size, they achieve the highest speed per body length of any bird. Grey-headed Albatrosses are known for their exceptional long-distance flight capabilities. These birds can maintain a speed of approximately 79 mph for eight hours at a stretch, making them nature's marathon fliers. They can travel about 16,000 kilometers in under two weeks, which is a testament to their incredible stamina and speed.
gold:

| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Peregrine Falcon | 240 | 14-19 | Streamlined body, powerful wing muscles |
| 2 | Golden Eagle | 200 | N/A | impressive size and prowess |
| 3 | Grey-headed Albatross | 79 | N/A | Long-distance flight capabilities, stamina |
| 4 | Anna's Hummingbird | 60 | 4 | Small, highest speed per body length |
output:
| Name | Body Length | Features Contribute to Speed |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Peregrine Falcon | 14-19 inches | Streamlined body, powerful wing muscles |
| Golden Eagles | 28-32 mph |  |
| Anna's Hummingbird | 4 inches |  |

instruction: List the information of fictions based on the reviews.
text: Nora Roberts' Dark Witch: 4 stars. Great world-building, weak romance, but still worth the read I hesitate to describe this book as a 'romance' novel simply because the book spent little time actually exploring the romance between Iona and Boyle. Sure, there IS a romance in this novel. Sprinkled throughout the book are a few scenes where Iona and Boyle meet, chat, wink at each, flirt some more, sleep together, have a misunderstanding, make up, and then profess their undying love. Very formulaic stuff, and all woven around the more important parts of this book The meat of this book is far more focused on the story of the Dark witch and her magically-gifted descendants living in Ireland. Despite being weak on the romance, I really enjoyed it. I think the book is probably better for it, because the romance itself was pretty lackluster stuff Ernest Cline's Ready Player One Video-game players embrace the quest of a lifetime in a virtual world; screenwriter Cline's first novel is old wine in new bottles The real world, in 2045, is the usual dystopian horror story. So who can blame Wade, our narrator, if he spends most of his time in a virtual world? The 18-year-old, orphaned at 11, has no friends in his vertical trailer park in Oklahoma City, while the OASIS has captivating bells and whistles, and it's free. Its creator, the legendary billionaire James Halliday, left a curious will. He had devised an elaborate online game, a hunt for a hidden Easter egg. The finder would inherit his estate. Old-fashioned riddles lead to three keys and three gates. Wade, or rather his avatar Parzival, is the first gunter (egg-hunter) to win the Copper Key, first of three Malcolm Gladwell's Outliers I've heard a lot of great things about Malcolm Gladwell's writing. Friends and co-workers tell me that his subjects are interesting and his writing style is easy to follow without talking down to the reader. I wasn't disappointed with Outliers. In it, Gladwell tackles the subject of success - how people obtain it and what contributes to extraordinary success as opposed to everyday success The thesis - that our success depends much more on circumstances out of our control than any effort we put forth - isn't exactly revolutionary. Most of us know it to be true. However, I don't think I'm lying when I say that most of us also believe that we if we just try that much harder and develop our talent that much further, it will be enough to become wildly successful, despite bad or just mediocre beginnings. Not so, says Gladwell.
gold:
| Author | Book Title | Rating (Out of 5) | Main Theme(s) | Key Points |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Nora Roberts | Dark Witch | 4 | Paranormal romance, magic | Weak romance, great world-building, focuses more on the story of the Dark Witch and her descendants |
| Ernest Cline | Ready Player One | N/A | Dystopia, Virtual Reality, Adventure | Set in 2045's dystopian world, the protagonist spends most of his time in a virtual world. The story revolves around an online game where the winner inherits a billionaire's estate |
output:
| Book | Nora Roberts' Dark Witch | Stars | 4 |
| Author | Ernest Cline | Stars | 3 |
| Subject | Ready Player One | Stars | 4 |
| Subject | Outliers | Stars | 3 |

instruction: Summarize the information of tornados with top-2 casulties in recored history
text: The most 'extreme' tornado in recorded history was the Tri-State tornado, which spread through parts of Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana on March 18, 1925. It is considered an F5 on the Fujita Scale, even though tornadoes were not ranked on any scale at the time. It holds records for longest path length at 219 miles (352 km), longest duration at about 3½ hours, and it held the fastest forward speed for a significant tornado at 73 mph (117 km/h) anywhere on Earth until 2021. In addition, it is the deadliest single tornado in United States history with 695 fatalities.[1] It was also the third most costly tornado in history at the time, but has been surpassed by several others non-normalized. When costs are normalized for wealth and inflation, it still ranks third today. The deadliest tornado in world history was the Daulatpur-Saturia tornado in Bangladesh on April 26, 1989, which killed approximately 1,300 people.[3] In the history of Bangladesh at least 19 tornadoes killed more than 100 people each, almost half of the total for the rest of the world. For 37 years, the most extensive tornado outbreak on record, in almost every category, was the 1974 Super Outbreak, which affected a large area of the central United States and extreme southern Ontario in Canada on April 3 and April 4, 1974. Not only did this outbreak feature 148 tornadoes in only 18 hours, but an unprecedented number of them were violent; 7 were of F5 intensity and 23 were F4. During the peak of this outbreak there were 16 tornadoes on the ground at the same time. More than 300 people, possibly as many as 330, were killed by tornadoes during this outbreak. However, this record was later broken during the 2011 Super Outbreak, which resulted in 360 tornadoes and 324 tornadic fatalities.[4] However, the most tornadoes spawned in the shortest amount of time is 104 over 5 hours and 26 minutes, during the 1981 United Kingdom tornado outbreak on 23 November 1981.
gold:
| Tornado Event | Location | Date | Estimated Deaths | Fujita Scale Ranking | Duration | Path Length | Max Speed | Notable Records |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Tri-State Tornado | Missouri, Illinois, Indiana (US) | March 18, 1925 | 695 | F5 | 3.5 hours | 219 miles (352 km) | 73 mph (117 km/h) | Longest path length, longest duration, fastest forward speed (until 2021), deadliest in US |
| Daulatpur-Saturia Tornado | Daulatpur-Saturia, Bangladesh | April 26, 1989 | ~1300 | Unknown | Unknown | Unknown | Unknown | Deadliest tornado in world history |
output:
| Top 2 Casualties in Recorded History |
| -------------------------------- |
| Tri-State Tornado (1925) | 695 Fatalities |
| Daulatpur-Saturia Tornado (1989) | 1,300 Fatalities |

instruction: Given the context, extract the name, height, city, country, floors, and year of top-2 tallest buildings that built after 2015.
text: Merdeka 118, formerly known as Warisan Merdeka Tower, KL 118 and PNB 118, is a 118-story megatall skyscraper in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. At 678.9 m (2,227 ft) tall, it is the second-tallest structure and the second-tallest building in the world, behind the Burj Khalifa at 828 m (2,717 ft). The building's name, Merdeka (which literally means 'independence'), is inspired by its proximity to Stadium Merdeka. The spire of the building was completed in October 2021, which marked its final height of 678.9 m (2,227 ft) above ground and 717.6 m (2,354 ft) above sea level. The Burj Khalifa (known as the Burj Dubai prior to its inauguration in 2010) is a skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It is the world's tallest building. With a total height of 829.8 m (2,722 ft, or just over half a mile) and a roof height (excluding antenna, but including a 242.6 m spire[2]) of 828 m (2,717 ft), the Burj Khalifa has been the tallest structure and building in the world since its topping out in 2009, supplanting Taipei 101, the previous holder of that status. The Ping An Finance Center (Chinese: 平安金融中心; pinyin: píng'ān jīnróng zhōngxīn) is a 115-storey, 599.1 m (1,966 ft) supertall skyscraper in Shenzhen, Guangdong, China.[7] The building was commissioned by Ping An Insurance and designed by the American architectural firm Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates. It was completed in 2017,[1] and is the tallest building in Shenzhen, the 2nd tallest building in China and the 5th tallest building in the world.[8][3] It also broke the record of having the highest observation deck in a building at 562 m (1,844 ft).[9] It is the second largest skyscraper in the world by floor area after Azabudai Hills Main Tower in Tokyo, Japan. Tianjin CTF Finance Center is a super-tall skyscraper located in the TEDA CBD of Binhai, Tianjin, China. Construction started in 2013 and was completed in 2019.[1] The tower is the second-tallest building in Municipal Tianjin after Goldin Finance 117, eighth-tallest building in the world, and the tallest building in the world with fewer than 100 floors.[2] It is located in the outer district of the Tianjin Economic-Technological Development Area. Tianjin CTF Finance Center is designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill LLP in collaboration with Ronald Lu & Partners. The building was honored with the Tall/Slender Structure award at the 2021 Awards Ceremony by the Institution of Structural Engineers (IStructE).[3]
gold:
| Building Name | Height (m/ft) | City | Country | Number of Floors | Completion Year |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Merdeka 118 | 678.9 m / 2,227 ft | Kuala Lumpur | Malaysia | 118 | 2021 |
| Tianjin CTF Finance Center | 530 m / 1,740 ft | Tianjin | China | 97 | 2019 |

Name: Merdeka 118
City: Kuala Lumpur
Country: Malaysia
Floors: 118
Year Built: 2015

Name: PNB 118
City: Kuala Lumpur

Floors: 118
Year Built: 2015

text: Substrate assays with BrvH were carried out with PrnF and ADH for cofactor regeneration as described by (Frese et al. 17). 1.25 mg/mL enzyme was incubated with 1 mM substrate for 48 h, 500 rpm, at 25 °C in 100 mM Na2HPO4 buffer and 1 μM FAD, 100 μM NAD, 50 mM NaBr, 2.5 U/mL PrnF, 2 U/mL RR-ADH and 5% (v/v) iso-propanol. text:
Google News is a news aggregator service developed by Google. It presents a continuous flow of links to articles organized from thousands of publishers and magazines. Google News is available as an app on Android, iOS, and the Web.

instruction: Extract the date of founding, location, and the representative directions in computer science for each university. List the results into a table.
text:
Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT): Founded in 1861, MIT is located in the city of Cambridge, Massachusetts. Its Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science is the largest in the university, fostering a vibrant interdisciplinary environment. Known for its robust blend of theory and practice, MIT's computer science curriculum has been instrumental in pioneering research areas such as artificial intelligence, systems, cryptography, and theoretical computer science. The institute's contributions to computer science have played a significant role in shaping the digital world as we know it.

University of California, Berkeley (UC Berkeley): Nestled in the city of Berkeley, California, UC Berkeley's EECS Department has been a cradle of innovation since the dawn of the information age. Known for its research in domains like artificial intelligence, data science, and systems, Berkeley's work often focuses on tangible applications, turning theory into practice. This strong connection to real-world challenges and its proximity to Silicon Valley provide an excellent platform for advancing computing technology and its uses.

Stanford University: Located in Stanford, California, Stanford's Computer Science Department is a powerhouse of technological advancement. Stanford's illustrious history includes significant contributions to the digital revolution, like the development of digital music and the birthplace of Google. The department is recognized for its cutting-edge research in artificial intelligence and robotics, systems, human-computer interaction, and theoretical computer science. Stanford's close relationship with Silicon Valley provides a unique synergy between academia and industry, leading to remarkable tech innovations.

Carnegie Mellon University (CMU): Founded in 1900 and located in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, CMU is recognized globally for its research and education in computer science. The university's School of Computer Science, a leading player in the field, is renowned for its strengths in areas such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, robotics, and software engineering. Additionally, CMU is celebrated for its groundbreaking interdisciplinary programs that blend computer science with other disciplines, leading to advancements in fields like computational biology, human-computer interaction, and computational finance. This broad application of computer science sets CMU apart as a leader in technological innovation.
gold:
| University | Date of Founding | Location | Representative Directions in Computer Science |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| MIT | 1861 | Cambridge, Massachusetts | Artificial Intelligence, Systems, Cryptography, and Theoretical Computer Science |
| UC Berkeley | N/A | Berkeley, California | Artificial Intelligence, Data Science, Systems |
| Stanford University | N/A | Stanford, California | Artificial Intelligence and Robotics, Systems, human-Computer Interaction, and Theoretical Computer Science |
| Carnegie Mellon University | 1900 | Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Robotics, Software Engineering, Computational Biology, Human-Computer Interaction, and Computational Finance |
output:
|University|Location|Representative Departments|
|Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)|Cambridge, Massachusetts|Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science|
|University of California, Berkeley (UC Berkeley)|Berkeley, California|Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science|
|Stanford University|Stanford, California|Department of Computer Science|
|Carnegie Mellon University (CMU)|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|School of Computer Science|

instruction: Recently I am reading a book about data mining. Here are the introduction. Extract the key information about the first chapter.
text:
1.	The chapters of this new edition are described briefly as follows, with emphasis on the new material.
2.	Chapter 1 provides an introduction to the multidisciplinary field of data mining. It discusses the evolutionary path of information technology, which has led to the need for data mining, and the im­portance of its applications. It examines various kinds of data to be mined, and presents a general classification of data mining tasks, based on the kinds of knowledge to be mined, the kinds of technolo­gies used, and the kinds of applications that are targeted. It shows that data mining is a confluence of multiple disciplines, with broad applications. Finally, it discusses how data mining may impact society.
3.	Chapter 2 introduces the data, measurements and data preprocessing. It first discusses data objects and attribute types, and then introduces typical measures for basic statistical data descriptions. It also introduces ways to measure similarity and dissimilarity for various kinds of data. Then, the chapter moves to introduce techniques for data preprocessing. In particular, it introduces the concept of data quality and methods for data cleaning and data integration. It also discusses various methods for data transformation and dimensionality reduction.
4.	Chapter 3 provides a comprehensive introduction to datawarehouses and online analytical process­ing [OLAP). The chapter starts with a well-accepted definition of data warehouse, an introduction to the architecture, and the concept of data lake. Then it studies the logical design of a data warehouse as a multidimensional data model, and looks at OLAP operations and how to index OLAP data for efficient analytics. The chapter includes an in-depth treatment of the techniques of building data cube as a way of implementing a data warehouse.
gold:
| Chapter Number | Title | Introduction and Overview | Topics Covered | Special Emphasis | Key Concepts | Interdisciplinary Aspects | Societal Impacts |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Introduction to Data Mining | Provides an introduction to the multidisciplinary field of data mining | Evolution of information technology; Need for data mining; Types of data; Classification of data mining tasks; Applications of data mining; Impact on society | Introduction to the multidisciplinary field of data mining; The importance of data mining applications | Data mining; Information technology evolution; Types of data; Data mining tasks | Confluence of multiple disciplines with broad applications | How data mining may impact society |
output:
Key Information: 
1. Data mining is a confluence of multiple disciplines with broad applications. 
2. Techniques for data preprocessing include data quality and methods for data cleaning and data integration. 
3. Data warehouses and online analytical processing (OLAP) are discussed.

instruction: According to the financial record, stocks surged higher on Friday. Give me more details about this situation.
text:
Stocks surged higher on Friday after a strong May jobs report and news late Thursday that the Senate passed the debt ceiling bill eased fears over a US debt default and a marked slowdown in the economy.

The S&P 500 (^GSPC) rose 1.45% while the Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) popped 1.07%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) led gains, rising 2.12%, or 701.1 points, and closing at a 1-month high. The S&P 500 closed the week at its highest level since since August 2022.

The US economy added 339,000 nonfarm payroll jobs last month while the unemployment rate rose to 3.7%, data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed Friday. This marks the 14th straight month that job creation came in above what Wall Street economists had expected.

Economists had expected the report to show payrolls rose by 195,000 while the unemployment rate was expected to tick up to 3.5%.

The US economy added 339,000 nonfarm payroll jobs last month while the unemployment rate rose to 3.7%, data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed Friday. This marks the 14th straight month that job creation came in above what Wall Street economists had expected.

Economists had expected the report to show payrolls rose by 195,000 while the unemployment rate was expected to tick up to 3.5%.

instruction: Analyzing and summarizing online recipes to extract key information for nutritional analysis.
text:
Begin by measuring out 340 grams of linguine or spaghetti, and 450 grams of large, shell-free, and deveined prawns. You'll also need a tablespoon of extra virgin olive oil, six finely chopped garlic cloves, a pinch of red pepper flakes, the zest and juice from one lemon, half a cup of freshly chopped parsley, and an optional half a cup of dry white wine. Don’t forget salt and black pepper for seasoning, and some grated Parmesan cheese for garnish. 
 Start the cooking process by boiling a large pot of salted water. Add the linguine or spaghetti to the boiling water and cook as per the instructions on the package, until it’s al dente. Once cooked, drain the pasta, but make sure to keep a cup of the pasta water aside for later. 
 In the meantime, as your pasta is cooking, grab a large skillet and heat the olive oil over medium heat. Toss in the finely chopped garlic and red pepper flakes, and sauté them briefly until the garlic starts to turn golden. Be careful not to burn the garlic. Now, add the prawns to the skillet and cook them until they’re opaque. This should take about 2-3 minutes on each side. 
 Once the prawns are cooked, pour in the white wine (if you’re using it), and let it simmer for a couple of minutes to cook off the alcohol. Now, lower the heat and add the lemon zest and juice, along with the chopped parsley. Season with salt and black pepper to your liking. 
 Your pasta should be ready by now. Add it to the skillet with the prawn mixture. Toss everything together, adding the reserved pasta water bit by bit, until you reach your desired sauce consistency. 
 Once everything is well combined and heated through, it’s time to serve! Divide the pasta among four plates, and garnish with a generous sprinkling of grated Parmesan cheese. Enjoy your Zesty Garlic Lemon Shrimp Linguine hot and bursting with flavors!
gold:
| Ingredient | Quantity | Preparation | Use |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Linguine or spaghetti | 340 grams | Boil in salted water untilal dente, drain | Main ingredient |
| Large prawns (shell-free, deveined) | 450 grams | Cook in skillet with garlic & pepper flakes | Mix with pasta |
| Extra virgin olive oil | 1 tablespoon | Heat in skillet | Sauté garlic & pepper flakes |
| Garlic cloves | 6 (finely chopped) | Sauté in olive oil | Flavor base for prawn sauce |
| Red pepper flakes | A pinch | Sauté with garlic | Adds heat to prawn sauce |
| Lemon | 1 | Zest and juice | Add to prawn sauce |
| Fresh parsley | 1/2 cup (chopped) | None | Add to prawn sauce |
| Dry white wine | 1/2 cup (optional) | Pour in skillet, simmer to cook off alcohol | Add to prawn sauce |
| Salt | To taste | Add to boiling water & prawn sauce | Seasoning |
| Black pepper | To taste | Add to prawn sauce | Seasoning |
| Grated Parmesan cheese | For garnish | None | Garnish on finished dish |
| Pasta water | 1 cup (reserved) | None | Adjust sauce consistency |
output:
| Key Ingredients | Amount |
| --------------- | --------- |
| linguine or spaghetti | 340 grams |
| large, shell-free, deveined prawns | 450 grams |
| extra virgin olive oil | 1 tablespoon |
| garlic cloves | 6 |
| red pepper flakes | 1/2 teaspoon |
| lemon zest and juice | 1/2 lemon |
| parsley | 1/2 cup |
| salt | 1 teaspoon |
| black pepper | 1 teaspoon |
| dry white wine | 1/2 cup |
| Parmesan cheese | 1/4 cup |

instruction: Aggregate up-to-date data from news reports involving an earthquake in Turkey.
text: On Feb. 6, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake occurred in southern Turkey near the northern border of Syria. This quake was followed approximately nine hours later by a magnitude 7.5 earthquake located around 59 miles (95 kilometers) to the southwest.The first earthquake was the most devastating to hit earthquake-prone Turkey in more than 20 years and was as strong as one in 1939, the most powerful recorded there. It was centered near Gaziantep in south-central Turkey, home to thousands of Syrian refugees and the many humanitarian aid organizations also based there.The Turkish government is leading the response there through coordination by AFAD and with the Turkish Red Crescent. State authorities declared a level-4 emergency leading to a call for international assistance. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan declared a three-month state of emergency in 10 of the country’s provinces.Governments around the world were quick to respond to requests for international assistance, deploying rescue teams and offering aid. The country of Turkey is recognized in English as Türkiye by the United Nations (UN).

instruction: The government releases a new policy document.  I want you to extract key details.
text:
This policy is intended to assist the California Department of Education in providing guidance to local educational agencies (LEAs) in welcoming, understanding, and educating the diverse population of students who are English learners attending California public schools. Many English learners represent the newest members of our society (including recently arrived immigrants and children of immigrants) who bring a rich diversity of cultural backgrounds and come from families with rich social and linguistic experiences. They also bring skills in their primary languages that contribute enormously to the state’s economic and social strengths as a talented multilingual and multicultural population.

This policy explicitly focuses on English learners in the context of the state’s efforts to improve the educational system, the quality of teaching and learning, and educational outcomes. It centers on standards, curriculum frameworks, assessment, accountability/school improvement, educator quality, early childhood/preschool, social and family support services, parent/community involvement, and higher education. Its purpose is to promote local capacity-building and continuous improvement in each of these areas and their interrelationship, based on evidence of effectiveness from local experience as well as the most current rigorous research evidence that speaks to the strengths and needs of the diverse population of English learners.

The impetus for this policy comes from a number of important related developments in California as well as nationally. If properly coordinated and articulated as part of a coherent California English Learner Roadmap, these developments can better serve the state’s large population of English learners to attain college- and career-ready standards and to further promote the rich linguistic diversity of the state as it thrives in a global economy and culture of learning, innovation, and advanced technology.

The adopted academic State Standards and the Next Generation Science Standards, and corresponding English Language Development (ELD) standards, signal an important shift toward emphasizing academic uses of language for all students, and student engagement with college- and career-ready curriculum using English and other languages. Taken together, these standards highlight the tightly interconnected nature of developing disciplinary content understandings, analytical practices, and academic uses of language for all students. This shift enables the educational system to move beyond remediating students’ English language skills to simultaneously developing their language and literacy skills while engaging in the full range of academic content learning.
gold:
| Policy Name | Purpose | Objective | Target Population | Schools | Student Background |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| California Department of Education | Provide guidance to LEAs | Welcome, understand, and educate | English learners | California public schools | Diverse cultural backgrounds |
output:
Key details extracted from the text: 
- The policy is intended to assist the California Department of Education in providing guidance to local educational agencies (LEAs) in welcoming, understanding, and educating the diverse population of students who are English learners attending California public schools. 
- Many English learners represent the newest members of our society (including recently arrived immigrants and children of immigrants) who bring a rich diversity of cultural backgrounds and come from families with rich social and linguistic experiences. 
- They also bring skills in their primary languages that contribute enormously to the state’s economic and social strengths as a talented multilingual and multicultural population. 
- This policy explicitly focuses on English learners in the context of the state’s efforts to improve the educational system, the quality of teaching and learning, and educational outcomes. 
- It centers on standards, curriculum frameworks, assessment, accountability/school improvement, educator quality, early childhood/preschool, social and family support services, parent/community involvement, and higher education. 
- Its purpose is to promote local capacity-building and continuous improvement in each of these areas and their interrelationship, based on evidence of effectiveness from local experience as well as the most current rigorous research evidence that speaks to the strengths and needs of the diverse population of English learners. 
- The impetus for this policy comes from a number of important related developments in California as well as nationally. 
- If properly coordinated and articulated as part of a coherent California English Learner Roadmap, these developments can better serve the state’s large population of English learners to attain college- and career-ready standards and to further promote the rich linguistic diversity of the state as it thrives in a global economy and culture of learning, innovation, and advanced technology. 
- The adopted academic State Standards and the Next Generation Science Standards, and corresponding English Language Development (ELD) standards, signal an important shift toward emphasizing academic uses of language for all students, and student engagement with college- and career-ready curriculum using English and other languages. Taken together, these standards highlight the tightly interconnected nature of developing disciplinary content understandings, analytical practices, and academic uses of language for all students. This shift enables the educational system to move beyond remediating students’ English language skills to simultaneously developing their language and literacy skills while engaging in the full range of academic content learning.

instruction: Carefully check the reports from non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to gather crucial information on effective human rights advocacy.
text:
Everyone has a right to life and liberty. Yet today, people with albinism still face human rights violations and extreme discrimination. Since 2006, more than 660 attacks on people with albinism in 30 countries have been recorded.



The persecution of people with albinism has been identified by the UN as a human rights issue. In countries in Africa, people with albinism are often called zeru zeru, meaning “ghost like creatures.” Too often, they are dehumanized by beliefs that say they are immortal or a curse, and as such, are misunderstood, abandoned, ostracized and sometimes even violently attacked or killed.



At more than 170 incidents, Tanzania has the largest recorded number of attacks. But attacks are on the rise in other countries now. Due to myths and superstitions about people with albinism, there is a black market for body parts, hair and skin used by witch doctors in potions and charms. The nature of attacks can range from maiming, to death, to desecrating their graves.
gold:
| Right | Issue | Term |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Right to life and liberty | Discrimination and human rights violations faced by people with albinism | Zeru Zeru (meaning "ghost-like creatures") |
| Persecution of people with albinism | Human rights issue identified by the UN | N/A |
| Albinism-related attacks | Tanzania (170+ incidents), other countries | Black market for body parts, hair, and skin |
| Nature of attacks | Range from maiming to death, desecration of graves | N/A |
| Superstitions and myths | Beliefs leading to dehumanization, abandonment, ostracization, and violence | Witch doctors using body parts, hair, and skin in potions and charms |
output:
| Type of Attack | Countries Affected |
| --- | --- |
| Physical Attacks | Tanzania |
| Myths and Superstitions | Multiple Countries |

instruction: Extracting vital data concerning water amount, result, and action from logs generated by water quality report
text:
In 2022, Chicago's tap water once again met or exceeded all standards set by the U.S. Environmental Protection
Agency for safe, clean drinking water. This annual report details information on results above detection limits
for annual certified testing of Chicago's drinking water.
The City of Chicago Department of Water Management (DWM) purifies and delivers 750 million gallons of clean
drinking water to residents of the City and 120 suburbs every day. DWM works tirelessly to keep our water clean
by:
• Performing over 600,000 analyses per year of tap water at every step in the treatment process and
adjusting treatment protocols as necessary;
• Using corrosion control in our water to minimize the risk of contaminants - including lead - from leaching
into water from plumbing;
• Providing complete instructions for whole house flushing, free NSF-certified water pitchers with six
cartridges for removing lead to residences and businesses where there is water infrastructure work being
done in the vicinity; and
• Offering completely free residential water testing by an independent certified laboratory.

instruction: I am interested in a book titled To Kill a Mockingbird. Here are the introduction about it. Tell me the concrete details about the book.
text:
To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by the American author Harper Lee. It was published in 1960 and was instantly successful. In the United States, it is widely read in high schools and middle schools. To Kill a Mockingbird has become a classic of modern American literature; a year after its release, it won the Pulitzer Prize. The plot and characters are loosely based on Lee's observations of her family, her neighbors and an event that occurred near her hometown of Monroeville, Alabama, in 1936, when she was ten.

Despite dealing with the serious issues of rape and racial inequality, the novel is renowned for its warmth and humor. Atticus Finch, the narrator's father, has served as a moral hero for many readers and as a model of integrity for lawyers.

instruction: Give me the key information from the reports provided by air traffic control systems. But only extract information that is different from the previous month
text: The April 2023 Traffic Report for JFK Airport reveals several key findings. The total number of revenue passengers reached 40,405, indicating a significant 12.7% increase compared to the previous month. Excluding general aviation, the passenger count stood at 38,971, with domestic travelers comprising 23,792 and international passengers totaling 15,179. Cargo flights experienced a slight 0.1% increase, with 1,581 flights recorded. In a year-over-year comparison, the total number of flights (excluding general aviation) decreased by 6.2%, primarily driven by an 8.6% decline in domestic flights and a 5.2% decrease in international flights. Notably, American, Qatar Airways, Turkish Air, Copa Airlines, and El Al faced the most significant declines in revenue passengers, while Delta, JetBlue Airways, British Airways, Cathay Pacific, and Korean witnessed substantial increases. The average load factors for domestic and international flights were reported as 81.8% and 85.3%, respectively. Furthermore, the report provides comprehensive passenger and freight statistics for various airlines, insights into market analysis across different regions, and details on passenger demographics such as gender, trip type, annual flights, and residency. Additionally, the report includes valuable information on airline schedules, encompassing non-stop destinations, carriers, and aircraft types.
gold:
| Metric | April 2023 | % Change from Previous Month |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Total Revenue Passengers | 40,405 | 12.7% |
| Cargo Flights | 1,581 | 0.1% |

Key Information from April 2023 Traffic Report for JFK Airport: 
- Total number of revenue passengers reached 40,405, indicating a significant 12.7% increase compared to the previous month. 
- Excluding general aviation, the passenger count stood at 38,971, with domestic travelers comprising 23,792 and international passengers totaling 15,179. 
- Cargo flights experienced a slight 0.1% increase, with 1,581 flights recorded. 
- In a year-over-year comparison, the total number of flights (excluding general aviation) decreased by 6.2%, primarily driven by an 8.6% decline in domestic flights and a 5.2% decrease in international flights. 
- American, Qatar Airways, Turkish Air, Copa Airlines, and El Al faced the most significant declines in revenue passengers, while Delta, JetBlue Airways, British Airways, Cathay Pacific, and Korean witnessed substantial increases. 
- The average load factors for domestic and international flights were reported as 81.8% and 85.3%, respectively. 
- Furthermore, the report provides comprehensive passenger and freight statistics for various airlines, insights into market analysis across different regions, and details on passenger demographics such as gender, trip type, annual flights, and residency. 
- Additionally, the report includes valuable information on airline schedules, encompassing non-stop destinations, carriers, and aircraft types.

instruction: Here are some descriptions of five kinds of fruits. I personally prefer red fruits. Extract some features of the fruits that I am interested in, including names, shapes, tastes, nutrients, and common uses.
text:
Strawberries are a popular fruit known for their vibrant red color and sweet, juicy flavor. They are heart-shaped, with a surface dotted with tiny yellow seeds. The green leafy cap is often present at the top. Strawberries are rich in vitamin C, antioxidants, and dietary fiber, making them a healthy choice for snacking or adding to various dishes and desserts. 
 One of the most widely consumed fruits, apples come in various colors, including red. Red apples typically have a shiny, smooth skin that can range from a pale pink to a deep crimson color. Their flesh is crisp and sweet with a slightly tart undertone. Rich in dietary fiber and vitamin C, they are often eaten fresh or used in recipes for pies, crisps, and juices. 
 Cherries are small, round fruits that are often deep red to maroon in color. They contain a single hard pit in the center. Cherries are known for their sweet and slightly tart flavor. They are rich in antioxidants, vitamin C, and potassium. Cherries are popular in pies, jams, and as a topping for desserts. They can also be enjoyed fresh, or dried for snacks. 
 Bananas are elongated, slightly curved fruits that have a thick, protective peel and soft, sweet flesh. The color of the peel changes from green to yellow as the fruit ripens. Bananas are an excellent source of potassium, vitamin B6, and dietary fiber. They can be eaten raw, added to smoothies, or used in baking and cooking, especially in dishes like banana bread and pancakes. 
 Kiwi, or kiwifruit, is an oval-shaped fruit with a fuzzy brown skin and vibrant green flesh. The flesh is speckled with tiny black seeds and has a sweet, tangy taste. Kiwi is packed with vitamin C and vitamin K, and is known for its digestive health benefits due to its high fiber content and the presence of actinidin, a natural enzyme. It can be eaten on its own, used in fruit salads, or as a topping for desserts and yogurt.
